North Carolina ranks 1st in the nation for rural clean energy jobs. It is vital we encourage and enable young people from all backgrounds and geographies in their STEM education.
All North Carolinians deserve the opportunity to pursue #STEM. Last week, I voted yes for the Rural STEM Education Research Act alongside my @HouseScience colleagues.

That is why I support the STEM Opportunities Act and the MSI STEM Achievement Act, to advance policies to address inequities in academic STEM careers and support critical initiatives to increase diversity in STEM.

Underrepresentation of women and people of color in #STEM weakens the industry and the economy. With diverse voices at the table, we can achieve greater inclusivity, innovation, equity, and prosperity.
To keep pace with industry growth, we must continue to support our students and researchers in their pursuit of STEM careers.

As a co-sponsor of the Supporting Early-Career Researchers Act to establish a new fellowship program for young researchers, I was thrilled to vote yes to pass this bill. The Research Triangle Park is the largest research park in America and a hub of #STEM innovation and talent.

Tackling our nation‚Äôs most pressing challenges requires embracing the potential of all young people interested in #STEM. I stand w/ my colleagues on @HouseScience who put forth critical legislation to provide equitable access to STEM education opportunities & STEM workforce.

Since the Supreme Court‚Äôs 2013 decision in Shelby County v. ¬†Holder, a number of states have adopted strict voter ID laws requiring voters to present a qualifying photo ID to vote. http://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1396862734847954947/pu/img/-y4C7yLpTYY9fYOi.jpg https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1396862734847954947/pu/vid/360x270/dFamNuMfQOpgtNR_.mp4?tag=12

"In multilingual polling places, multilingual poll workers are prepared for LEP voters and prepared to treat them with respect. Without multilingual poll workers, there is a higher risk of LEP voters encountering hostility from monolingual poll workers."

.@Tao_Minnis: "If a voter beats the odds and overcomes all the foregoing obstacles to register and to understand how to vote in a jurisdiction that does not provide effective language assistance, that voter must then undertake the daunting task to actually cast a ballot."
.@Tao_Minnis (@AAAJ_AAJC): ‚ÄúSome of the most significant barriers to free and fair access to the ballot for Asian Americans stem from the historical discrimination against Asian Americans.‚Äù

Dr. Barreto (@UCLALatino): "...The Voting Rights Act language provisions are settled law: where language-minority populations reach thresholds, state and local jurisdictions must provide non-English access to all voting materials that are otherwise available in English."

.@aesenteno: "The growing Latino population is often seen by the political establishment as a threat in many places. As a result, we are likely to see an increase in efforts to disenfranchise the Latino electorate, including many naturalized citizens..."

.@aesenteno (@maldef): "As the growth of the Latino population expands, states and localities have worked to
slow the registration and participation of new voters, and thus MALDEF‚Äôs work in voting rights continues to increase."

Professor Lajevardi (@michiganstateu): "Today, voter identification laws represent one of the nation‚Äôs most important barriers to voting, and thus, one of the country‚Äôs most important civil rights issues."

Campbell (@NDNrights): ‚ÄúFor most Americans, obtaining identification is a simple act of going to the local Department of Motor Vehicles (‚ÄúDMV‚Äù). For many American Indian and Alaska Natives, however, the process is not so simple and in fact severely burdensome.‚Äù

Atkeson: "While proper training can reduce poll worker discretion substantially, it likely cannot eliminate it[...]the county clerk has to be continuously vigilant because without constant emphasis during poll worker training discretion results in uneven implementation."

Atkeson: "Unequal application appears to be related to the interaction between the poll worker, the amount of discretion that poll workers have along with the complexity of the voter ID law, especially having different voter ID rules for different types of voters..."

Professor Atkeson (@UNM): ‚ÄúWhile most of the focus on issues related to voter ID policies has been on how they may affect turnout, an equally important and alternative question to consider is whether voter ID policies are administered equally across groups.‚Äù
